awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Challenging, Operationalizing, and Understanding Racialized and Gendered Events (COURAGE) in Undergraduate Mathematics
awd_abstract_narration:
Inadequate preparation of students in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) is a significant problem in the United States. In addition, historically marginalized groups, including women, African Americans, and Hispanics, are vastly underrepresented in the STEM workforce.  Research indicates that the reasons why women and historically marginalized students of color are unable or unwilling to pursue STEM majors are complex and multifaceted. One common factor often cited in the literature is the nature and quality of college mathematics instruction. Additionally, some researchers have suggested that the culture surrounding mathematics institutions, such as messages about mathematical ability being innate and the focus on individual competition, deters women and students of color. This suggests critical questions: What specific patterns of peer and instructor interactions contribute to or reinforce this mathematics learning culture? Why does this quality of instruction have a larger negative impact on women and students of color? What, specifically, makes this instruction inadequate in meeting the academic and social needs of underrepresented groups in mathematics? Do instructors recognize these actions as contributing to this underrepresentation in mathematics? Knowing the answers to these questions will contribute to creating more equitable mathematics learning environments at the undergraduate level and increasing the number of STEM majors to meet the demands of the national workforce. This Improving Undergraduate STEM Education (IUSE) Engaged Student Learning project, Challenging, Operationalizing and Understanding Racialized and Gendered Experiences (COURAGE) in Undergraduate Mathematics is designed to begin the process of finding these answers.

	There is little research on the relationship between undergraduate mathematics instruction and the retention and achievement of groups that are historically underrepresented in mathematics; other scholars have noted that research in this area is sparse and urgently needed. In order to study this relationship, this research project uses a mixed-methods design. The intellectual merit of COURAGE is directly related to the opportunity to advance knowledge in this under-examined area of STEM education, the design of the research project itself and the qualifications of the personnel involved. In the first year, through observational study and stimulus-recall interviews, the investigators will identify specific events in pre-calculus and calculus classrooms that women and students of color find potentially marginalizing, and will investigate the perceptions of these events from the vantage points of undergraduate mathematics instructors as well as students who are adequately represented and underrepresented in the STEM disciplines. In the second year, quantitative studies using focus group interviews and surveys will be conducted to assess the generalizability of these findings. In particular, videotaped classroom events will be presented to a national sample of undergraduate students and mathematics course instructors, to see the extent to which they find these instructional events to be typical, desirable, or problematic. In the third year, professional development materials will be designed and then piloted with instructors that intend to create more equitable learning environments in undergraduate mathematics classrooms. A critical outcome of this work will be a collection of materials including a synthesis of typical events in undergraduate mathematics classrooms that marginalize students, various students' documented perceptions of classroom events, and recommended instructional practices for more equitably responding to their occurrences that can be shared widely to the benefit of the broader STEM education community.

por.por_cntn:
The COURAGE project completed multiple qualitative analyses of: (i) historically marginalized student populations’ journaling of events in calculus instruction perceived as potentially supportive or unsupportive of their racial and gender identities; (ii) individual interviews with calculus students and instructors centered on stimulus prompts of instructional events developed from student journaling; and (ii) student group interviews with a similar structure involving stimulus prompts of events from calculus instruction. Analyses of student and instructor surveys that were developed based on these initial qualitative analyses are ongoing.

Findings from qualitative analyses indicate that historically marginalized student populations perceive social and institutional forces, including stereotypes of ability, underrepresentation of white women and racially minoritized students in mathematics classrooms, and departmental norms (e.g., use of calculus to sort students into and out of STEM majors), as contributing to their experiences of seemingly neutral instruction as racialized and gendered. Precalculus and calculus students across intersections of racial and gender identities varyingly perceive patterns of instructor behavior as shaping the potentially oppressive nature of instructional events. Most events that historically marginalized student populations reported as discouraging relate to instructors’ handling of contributions through classroom participation, thus challenging the ‘neutral’ status of teaching and learning contexts in undergraduate mathematics. Historically marginalized student populations, as a result, reported how they found themselves having to manage emotional and cognitive labor about how they are positioned in terms of being mathematically competent and belonging in STEM. Students reported strategically managing their participation in precalculus and calculus classrooms (e.g., not asking questions, avoiding office hours) to cope with this undue labor on top of trying to learn mathematics.

In addition, our findings demonstrate how historically marginalized student populations perceived practices of calculus instruction that are supportive for all students (regardless of racial and gender identities) to be necessary yet insufficient in fostering equitable learning opportunities. For example, inviting students to seek help during office hours without explicitly challenging racial and gender stereotypes of ability was perceived as an instructional practice that left historically marginalized student populations grappling with uncertainty if their help-seeking will confirm deficits in competence, thus reinforcing inequitable access to support.

Findings from the COURAGE project also indicate that instructors often invoke paternalistic, color-evasive, and gender-neutral discourses when reasoning about instructional practices in calculus. These lenses arguably limit the extent to which calculus instructors are conscious of how their classroom practices, while seemingly neutral, are being experienced in potentially oppressive ways among historically marginalized student populations. Findings from our interviews with white students capture how they similarly adopted a color-evasive lens by focusing on instructor intent rather than student impact in reasoning about the potentially racialized and gendered nature of instructional events. In contrast, historically marginalized students often interpreted events through multiple perspectives beyond instructor intent, which allowed them to consider variation more readily in how events are interpreted.

Taken together, findings from the COURAGE project elucidate racialized and gendered mechanisms of undergraduate calculus instruction to better understand how introductory mathematics courses reinforce the lack of social diversity in STEM fields. These findings have begun to inform the design of professional development opportunities in mathematics departments to support faculty with adopting race- and gender-conscious instructional practices that expand equitable learning opportunities in and beyond calculus courses.
